LGTM
Thanks @wtanaka for the contribution.

I just take a quick look to compare with what I did in #592. IMHO, this one is not what we want in Beam: this IO is basically a copy of `JdbcIO` updated for Cassandra. So basically, no splitting, no leveraging Cassandra features. I would recommend to close this PR and take a look on mine (I'm finalizing #592 this week).

Yeah, overall LGTM. Agreed with Ahmet about ugly expectations, fine as long as there's a comment. :) One thing to note though -- Maven has the ability to autodetect OS and we're doing that in our project somewhere -- it's possible we could only activate those options if we detect we're running on Windows. Thoughts? This has been in PR for a while and I think it'd be great to get in so if this is going to be a lot more work I'd bias towards just the comment and submit, but I figured it was worth mentioning.
Looks like this has been working well for us. I'm still following up on what's going on in the environment, so for now let's get this in. LGTM.

Thanks for your comments. Sorry for not bringing this to completion yet (haven't felt good lately).

OS (or Windows) detection is not a big deal in Groovy, it can be done in one line:
`System.properties['os.name'].toLowerCase(Locale.ROOT).contains('windows')`

If there is no objection I'd put this into the groovy script to have everything centralized there.
Will deliver this improvement today for review.

Thanks!
Awesome, sounds good!
Also, please don't interpret my comment above as impatience -- I haven't been super snappy about reviewing, which has slowed the process down. :) Hope you feel better soon.

Generally, having both setters (serializer and coder) makes sense. For convenience, it would be nice if the user didn't have to specify the coder in simple cases. I think you can try doing that by inferring the coder, if it's not specified explicitly, from the type of the serializer. Here are the steps for that:

* If a serializer is specified but coder is not, you can inspect the serializer's type using reflection and extract the type parameter of its base class.
* When applying the Read.from() transform to an input, you can use input.getPipeline().getCoderRegistry() to try inferring a coder for that type. Then you'll need to pass that coder into the Source object so you can return it from getDefaultOutputCoder() (by the way, I think that method should be nullable but currently isn't - I've filed https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-1820)
